author: @noahlong5030
text: Hey eddie, I was gonna post this on tiktok but there was a character limit so i thought i‚Äôd ask here. Do you believe the future will have less jobs due to automation? Marx believed that every worker should have all of the necessities to live, right? So what do we do as a society when there are less workers due to this? (feel free to answer this on tiktok too because I pretty much see all of your videos)

replies.author: @MidwesternMarx
replies.text: Definitely. It‚Äôs a contradiction that productivity has increased so much, while hours worked has stayed daily stagnant. Automation should liberate society, not push people into unemployment. A contradiction that can be solved with worker ownership of the MOP

author: @ThankYouBasedGod1738
text: a good question to ask bay area is : what is China doing for the global left post Deng reforms? like aiding socialist movements throughout the world? They dropped the support for the Maoists back in the 90s or sum. I think China is going for a non-interventionist approach unlike the USSR who helped a lot of movements.

replies.author: @MidwesternMarx
replies.text: If you read Xi Jinping‚Äôs book it answers a lot of those questions. Post reforms there have been anti corruption efforts, a return to Mao‚Äôs thought, and other evolutions  of Deng era policies. He also talks about their non interventionist approach, which they call foreign policy of mutual development. Like you said, it is to avoid the interventionism of the USSR.

replies.author: @Dhumm81
replies.text: @MidwesternMarx   "Non interventionist"...but happy to sell arms to fascist regimes to slaughter socialists for a high enough *PROFIT!* (Philippines, etc.).

replies.author: @exu7325
replies.text: @Dhumm81 This bullshit talking point is easily debunked by public records. China has NEVER sold a single arms to Philippines or Israel in its history.

replies.author: @Dhumm81
replies.text: @exu7325 Philippines: December 2016.

replies.author: @exu7325
replies.text:
@Dhumm81 Well, let's see Philippines' arms import in the year 2016, shall we? (source: trendeconomy)

Top trading partners (import of "Military weapons, other than revolvers, pistols and the arms of heading 93.07.") of Philippines in 2016:

Bulgaria with a share of 88% (1.35 million US$)
Israel with a share of 8.56% (130 thousand US$)
USA with a share of 1.85% (28 thousand US$)
Turkey - 9.3 thousand US$

And arms of heading 9307 are basically just knives. Like I said, easily debunked by public records. There are legitimate criticisms that can be made against the PRC, there's really no need to make up slanderous bullshit talking points.

author: @MyAce8
text: Before getting to my criticisms I'd like to preface what I'm about to say by saying that I really love a lot of the stuff you guys put out and I want to be as good faith as possible. That being said I vehemently disagree with your perspective on China. While it is true China represents a progressive force in many aspects, especially in how it challenges western economic hegemony, and has vastly improved the lives of hundreds of millions the CPC is not a force for socialism. One of the most obvious examples of this truth is labour relations. The removal of the right to strike from the constitution during the liberal economic reforms is symbolic of a wider trend of siding with domestic capitalists over workers. This isn't a conspiracy either ACFTU openly talks about opposing strikes on the basis that it would harm domestic capitalists, often justifying their actions by appealing to nationalism. Not only is there no recognition of non-CPC affiliated worker's organizations, state power is regularly utilized to crush wildcat strikes and independent worker movements. Their lack of commitment to socialism is also visible in hong kong where they actively support parties that are economically conservative by even western standards. Given that many MLs speak positively of similarly mangled top-down "workers" organizations like the AFL-CIO its possible that the origin of this disagreement goes all the way down to the fundamental differences between the Anarchist and ML perspectives and I stand no chance of convincing you. That being said I hope you get around to responding, and keep up the good work comrade!

replies.author: @McHobotheBobo
replies.text:
A few comments:
China is not a monolith, labor regulations vary by city and province, and though in SEZs workers rights are definitely reduced there are plenty of incidents of police and courts supporting workers in labor disputes.

Allow independent worker organizations? Are you mad? The so-called "Solidarity," movement crushed socialist Poland and gave us the far-right state we have today. Do you want to see something similar in China? Further as someone who has in the past been affiliated with the AFL-CIO the organization is not comparable to the labor unions of China. Totally different models, the unions of China have direct representation in national legislature ffs! 

Also I don't know any MLs with positive opinions of American unions beyond that they're better than nothing

replies.author: @MyAce8
@MidwesternMarx
replies.text: Most MLs I know refer to the AFL-CIO as the AFL-CIA haha. A lot of times isolated incidents of ‚Äúworker suppression‚Äù are often blown up by Western media to promote a narrative about China. Labour regulations in China aren‚Äôt hegemonic, and vary by region. Statistically Chinese workers actually go on strike more than any other country, Google it! I would check out Michael Hudson‚Äôs recent work on a China if you want to know more about their economic plans. Xi Xingping and Deng have also written books with daily detailed plans for the country, and the goal remains to build ‚Äúsocialism with Chinese characteristics‚Äù. It sometimes seems like some leftists are rooting against China reaching this goal. We choose to remain critical, but in strong support of the goal of building socialism.

replies.author: @MyAce8
replies.text: @MidwesternMarx Do you have any particular recommendations for good sources when comparing strike frequency across countries? I'm also curious how effective they are. One of the things I found really interesting when reading about Vietnam was although in Vietnam the unions usually advocate against striking they actually do a pretty good job of protecting workers when wildcat strikes do arise.

replies.author: @MyAce8
replies.text: @MidwesternMarx I'd also like to add that most of my criticism of the CPC aren't from a moral perspective where I think they are corrupt and I could do a better job. Just that the nature of the state is that certain interest groups must be appeased in order for state power to be maintained, and if the working class doesn't continue to engage in class struggle the state will lose the pressure to balance the needs for workers. Because of this viewing the CPC as the revolutionary agent in China seems wrong to me. When analyzing internal conflicts within countries whose government calls itself socialist I find MLs quick to criticize popular movements. I've remember getting into similar arguments when MLs I knew who were turned on FSTMB, COB, and other popular Bolivian organizations  when the criticized MAS

replies.author: @francoisrenaito6933
replies.text: You may be right, in some things, but the point of the revolutionary struggle is not to criticize the one who is looking for the right path, the point is to criticize the one who is on the wrong path,It is the imperialist government of the United States, the criminal of humanity that we must all strongly criticize.

replies.author: @exu7325
replies.text: I'm sorry, but anarchists should be the last persons to opinionate on whether anything is a "force for socialism" or not. Anarchism has achieved NOTHING.
